A landmark Supreme Court decision in 2022 made it easier for Americans to carry handguns in public, influencing the legal reasoning around gun prohibitions based on drug use.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same federal law and later pardoned by President Joe Biden.
The case references the 2020 U.S. drone strike that killed Qasem Soleimani, which is tied to allegations in the Hemani case about travel to Iran.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing firearms, specifically addressing whether such a ban violates the Second Amendment.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual citizen of the U.S. and Pakistan, who was prosecuted for possessing a 9mm pistol, 60 grams of marijuana, and 4.7 grams of cocaine at his family home, with the government citing his habitual marijuana use.
A federal district court dismissed the charge, citing the 2022 Supreme Court decision that requires gun prohibitions to have historical precedent.
The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the government cannot target habitual drug users, arguing that such laws lack historical analogs.
The Trump administration appealed that decision, claiming habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially during encounters with law enforcement.
The government alleged Hemani had ties to Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps affiliates and traveled to Iran to celebrate Qasem Soleimani’s life, though these claims were challenged in the case.

Hemani’s legal team argued that the historical foundation for the law is weak and that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana, creating a significant overlap between legal marijuana users and firearm ownership.
Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, was convicted in 2024 under the same law and later pardoned by President Biden, highlighting the law’s national and political sensitivity.

This case is part of a broader trend in the Supreme Court’s gun-related rulings, following the 2022 decision allowing more public handgun carrying and the 2024 decision upholding gun bans for domestic abuse victims.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, focusing on whether such a ban violates the Second Amendment. The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual citizen of the U.S. and Pakistan, who was indicted in 2023 after the FBI found a 9mm pistol, marijuana, and cocaine at his home, with the government citing his habitual marijuana use. A lower court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court decision that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots. The 5th Circuit ruled that such a ban cannot apply to habitual users, but the Trump administration appealed, arguing that such users pose a danger to public safety, especially while impaired. The government also alleged Hemani’s ties to Iran and connections to the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, though these claims remain disputed. Hemani's legal team countered that the historical basis for the law is weak, noting that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana. The case is politically charged, highlighted by the fact that Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned. The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2025, potentially setting a precedent on the balance between public safety and constitutional rights in gun ownership.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
